text: A ring chromosome is when two ends of a chromosome come together and look like a ring. This can happen to any chromosome. It was first discovered in 1926 by American biologist Lilian Vaughan Morgan. There are many different symptoms someone may have if they have a ring chromosome. The most common symptom is a delay in growth. Most of the time, ring chromosomes happen randomly. About 1 in 50,000 people have a ring chromosome. == Formation == Most of the time, a ring chromosome will happen if the two ends of one chromosome are missing. This allows the ends to combine together to form a ring. Sometimes, the ends of the chromosomes won't be missing, but this is very rare. When this happens, the phenotype (appearance and body) of someone is usually normal. They usually do not know they have a ring chromosome. Ring chromosomes can be very complicated. Sometimes, small parts of the chromosome may be missing (microdeletion) or there may be a copy of it (microduplication). Sometimes, someone may have three chromosomes (trisomy) instead of two with the extra chromosome being a ring chromosome. Any chromosome can be a ring chromosome. == Ring chromosome syndromes == A ring chromosome syndrome is any genetic disorder that is caused by a ring chromosome. About 1 in 50,000 people have a ring chromosome syndrome. The symptoms vary based on which chromosome is the ring chromosome. Most of the time, the symptoms vary widely, even in the same ring chromosome syndrome. However, most syndromes with a ring chromosome affect the way someone's body grows. === List of ring chromosome syndromes === Chromosome Common symptoms Prevalence Ring chromosome 1 Microcephaly
